pli-tv-bi-vb-ss13:1.5: In the sequence uññāya paribhavena akkhantiyā vebhassiyā dubbalyā every word seems to be in the instrumental case except dubbalyā, which presumably is an ablative. This is unusual. The commentary, at Sp.2.727, says: Dubbalyāti tumhākaṃ dubbalabhāvena, “Dubbalyā: because of your weakness.” This implies that dubbalyā is the only word in the sequence that does not refer to the Sangha, but rather to the misbehaving nuns, which would be odd. Yet the commentarial interpretation is supported by the word commentary below, which defines dubbalyā as apakkhatā , “because of lack of supporters”. I therefore feel compelled to follow the commentarial interpretation.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss13:2.77: The Pali text just says dukkaṭa, without specifying that it is an āpatti, an offense. Yet just below the text says that the dukkaṭa is annulled if you commit the full offense of saṅghādisesa. The implication is that dukkaṭa should be read as āpatti dukkaṭassa, “an offense of wrong conduct”.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss13:3.14: Nuns’ suspension 14, 15, 16, and 17 are respectively identical to the monks’ suspension 10 at Bu Ss 10:0.4, 11 at Bu Ss 11:0.4, 12 at Bu Ss 12:0.4, and 13 at Bu Ss 13:0.4, with appropriate gender changes.
